name: thedailybeast
text:
Broadway League president Charlotte St. Martin has her own criteria for reopening Broadway.

It won't be until “it’s safe to sit next to each other and for the cast and crew to be dancing and kissing and everything else they do, sweating on each other.” https://t.co/CGLxyEPhIK

name: thedailybeast
text:
“We can’t socially distance the cast and crew in these 100-year-old-plus buildings,” St. Martin told @TimTeeman. 

“And we can’t afford to socially distance the audience. https://t.co/zvEGdNXHLV

name: thedailybeast
text:
St. Martin said that in the last ten weeks of being closed, Broadway has been losing an average of $35 million a week, and relaunching would also be costly.

“We do anticipate some loss of business when we reopen,” she said. https://t.co/zvEGdNXHLV

name: thedailybeast
text:
There has been talk of socially-distanced new ways of performing, new ways of seeing shows; of fewer performers, fewer audience members. 

But St. Martin sees the reborn Broadway as much like the old Broadway as possible—just with more protection. https://t.co/zvEGdNXHLV

name: thedailybeast
text: In the Broadway of the future, St. Martin tells @TimTeeman, “I think you’ll probably see a lot of contactless activities, like with scanning tickets, and no faucets and hand flushes in the restrooms.” https://t.co/zvEGdNXHLV

name: thedailybeast
text:
“This is a time of uncertainty, but at the end of the day I believe we will be back, and eventually we will be back to where we were before.”

Read the full exclusive interview with Charlotte St. Martin here: https://t.co/zvEGdNXHLV
